p: The interaction of viral components with various receptors activates the intracellular pathways responsible for the secretion of type I IFN, pro-inflammatory cytokines, and chemokines. The key factors involved in the recognition of viral ligands are the Toll-like receptors (TLRs) of innate immune cells. TLR2 and TLR4, situated on the cell surface, recognize viral envelope glyco/lipoproteins, while intracellular endosomal TLR3, TLR7, TLR8, and TLR9 recognize nucleic acids [ 3, 4]. Toll-like receptors can interact with other receptors, thereby stimulating the response of innate immune cells to pathogens, including influenza viruses [ 4]. TLR4 can be activated by damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs), which are molecular structures released by virus-infected cells [ 5]. Different influenza strains activate cells through various mechanisms, which lead to the synthesis of various cytokines and chemokines [ 6, 7].
